title: Are modern Smartphones camera as good as DSLR? - Quora

response.answer_text: They’re definitely not as good in the traditional sense, but they’re capable of taking great photos despite their limitations. Take a look at the Samsung Galaxy S6 phone (16 MP ) compared to the Nikon D750 (24 MP) full frame camera. At this size, the differences are hardly noticeable. Samsung on the left. ISO 100.  Even at ISO 800, the phone holds up quite well at this resolution.  A closer look and the differences are very apparent. The small phone sensor just can’t compete (and we wouldn’t expect it to). ISO 800    ISO 100  Man this phone seems to be doing an awesome job. Pretty crazy when you consider the difference in sensor size. Samsung in green. Nikon in blue.  Pixel size comparison: Samsung: 1.12 µm | Nikon 5.9µm Don’t forget that this comparison was done under ideal conditions, in decent light, on a still subject, in a controlled environment. I’m certainly not going to use my iPhone for any serious work, but I have no doubt that one can take great photos with a phone camera. . Test images: Digital Cameras, Digital Camera Reviews .

From the table, we can see that in some cases the image quality from a smartphone can actually be better than that from a DSLR. But we can also see that smartphone results are much less consistent, and therefore it isn't possible right now to trust our smartphones to always provide a quality image. Smartphones will never supersede cameras, but they'll remain powerful tools that you can carry in your pocket at all times, to use as a compact option that compliments the quality and control offered by your DSLR or mirrorless camera. While DSLRs seem to be losing ground to mirrorless cameras as the years go on, they are still the go-to tools of many photographers because they are often the best for the job. The recent spate of announcements from Nikon and Canon make it clear: It's probably the best time ever to buy a DSLR. Go to my Profile and you can find all about Photography material there...

Simply no. They can be really good for what they do, but it’s a bit like comparing a bicycle with a car. The bicycle can be very modern, stylish, light and effective, but it’s still a different thing even compared to a standard car. I can’t go into the details of what DSLR can do on top of what phone camera can do, this would require a comprehensive photography course, but trust me when I say that whilst phone cameras can be really great you won’t see proper journalist taking pictures of the president with their phones or someone serious about a safari in Africa going with just their iPhone.

Just as good? No, but they are getting damn close! I recently posted a blog where I tested my iphone SE against my canon 1200D. Both systems set in automatic and under same conditions, the result? Judge yourself.     I personally find the phone-camera picyures to be more sharp across the board and work better in low light, but the 1200D shots are more pleasing to look at. The full blog and high resolution inages can be found here. Thommy Saltzherr's post in thphotography blog

You only ask this because you don't really understand exactly what a modern DSLR does. One quick thing is that DSLR can accept lens from extreme wide angle lens from like 8mm to ultra telephoto 1000mm. Macro lenses that you can easily shot up to 2x life-size. Or take a bunch of fast moving actions. This goes on. Now if you only want it to take pictures of the kids and on vacation and selfies. Then a mobile phone may be e best for u.

“As good as” can also be subjective. In my case, i find my Huawei P20 Pro to be BETTER than my Nikon D5300 and Fujifilm XT-2 in low-light situations or for indoors in general. Am no pro and am far from exploiting the full functionalities of my DLSR/mirrorless cameras. Perhaps they are better in the hands of experts, but for an enthusiast like me, the AI technology of the new phone cameras is an ally i appreciate.

In one important way, smart phones are much better than any DSLR- you always carry yours with you at all times. If a great photo opportunity presents itself you can have a camera in your hands ready to capture the photo in seconds. You won’t miss the shot. If you use a DSLR it is highly unlikely that you will carry it around with you at all times and you will certainly miss many shots that you see and regret not capturing. As has been said, “The best camera you have is the one you have with you.”

No, they are not. They are great for many practical uses, but they are not the same thing, that's why comparisons would be unfair for both. You first have to define what you want to do, and what results you need to obtain to select the proper tool. Cheers!
Q: What DSLR cameras are outperformed by smartphones? Broken ones.

The recent smart phones have good camera. However, the Quality of a DSLR is much better. The zoom and depth of field control with a DSLR cannot be achieved with a smartphone. Take a panoramic photo with smart phone and DSLR ( same photo ). Watch and rcompare the photo on laptop.

The simple answer is “no”; but if you use the “panorama” option on your smartphone, you can maximize the quality and get photos that come as close as possible to those from a DSLR.  Using panorama mode allows the smartphone camera to get a lot more resolution (and higher pixel count) into a single image.  There are times when I have my DSLR with me, but use my iPhone for panoramas.

IF you restrict it to ‘con-currently available’ NO! today’s phone camera may have similar final capability as early DSLR technology. In general, a single purpose [especially electronic] device will always be able to outperform a multi-purpose one

I guess smartphone camera’s might be able to compete with DSLR’s but not in the near future. This is mainly due to the physical restrictions of the small chassis of a smartphone. While smartphones might be a good substitute to a DSLR, they will not be able to replace them on a whole any time soon.
No smartphones can compete any DSLR because phones are made for multi purpose and DSLRs are made only to capture photos. But iphone 7+ camera is good as DSLR but it is only for portrait.
